steps.explanation: Distance from x-axis in Quadrant II.
Standard angle value from π/6 family.
ASTC: All Students Take Calculus (sine positive in Q-II).

solutions.whenToUse: Universal method for any angle using reference angles.

commonMistakes.correct: \text{Sine is positive in Quadrant II, so } +\frac{1}{2}
commonMistakes.why: ASTC rule: sine positive in Quadrants I and II.
Reference angle gives magnitude; quadrant gives sign.
Must memorize correct values for π/6 family.

steps.explanation: ASTC: cosine positive in Quadrants I and IV.

solutions.whenToUse: Standard method for unit circle values.

commonMistakes.why: ASTC: All (Q-I), Sine (Q-II), Tangent (Q-III), Cosine (Q-IV).
Reference angle is always from x-axis, not nearest axis.

steps.explanation: Distance from negative x-axis in Q-III.
ASTC: tangent positive in Quadrants I and III.

solutions.whenToUse: Standard approach for tangent values.
When you want to verify or use ratio definition.

commonMistakes.correct: \text{Tangent is positive in Q-III (both sin and cos negative)}
commonMistakes.why: Tangent = sin/cos; two negatives make a positive.

commonMistakes.correct: \tan(\pi/3) = \sqrt{3} \text{ (not the same as sin or cos)}
commonMistakes.why: Tangent has different values than sine and cosine.

solutions.strategy: Identify quadrants where cosine is negative

steps.latex: \text{Cosine is negative in Quadrants II and III}
steps.explanation: ASTC rule: cosine positive in Q-I and Q-IV only.
π minus reference angle for Q-II.
π plus reference angle for Q-III.

solutions.whenToUse: Finding all solutions in a given interval.

commonMistakes.correct: \text{Only Q-II and Q-III where cosine is negative}

steps.explanation: Sine is an odd function: sin(-x) = -sin(x).

solutions.whenToUse: Evaluate each trig expression independently, then combine.

commonMistakes.why: Must apply odd function property for negative angles.
Must check quadrant for sign.

steps.explanation: Cosine of π/4 is √2/2, negative in Q-II.

solutions.whenToUse: For secant, cosecant, cotangent: use reciprocal identities.

commonMistakes.correct: \text{In Q-II, cosine is negative, so secant is negative}
commonMistakes.why: Secant has same sign as cosine.
Dividing by a fraction means multiplying by its reciprocal.

steps.explanation: Factor difference of squares: a² - b² = (a-b)(a+b).

solutions.whenToUse: Standard approach for simplifying trig expressions.

commonMistakes.correct: \text{Cannot split fraction this way; must manipulate algebraically}
commonMistakes.why: Division distributes only over addition in numerator, not this form.
Difference of squares: a² - b² = (a-b)(a+b).

problems.prompt: \text{Prove the identity: } \tan x + \cot x = \sec x \csc x

steps.latex: \tan x + \cot x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} + \frac{\cos x}{\sin x}

steps.explanation: Common denominator: sin x cos x.
Reciprocal identities: csc x = 1/sin x, sec x = 1/cos x.

solutions.whenToUse: Standard approach: convert everything to sin and cos.

commonMistakes.why: Must use common denominator.
This is the key step to simplify the numerator.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Prove: tan x + cot x = sec x csc x
chunkedSteps: LHS: sin x/cos x + cos x/sin x
Common denominator: (sin²x + cos²x)/(sin x cos x)
= 1/(sin x cos x) = csc x sec x

steps.explanation: Cancel one factor of cos x.

solutions.whenToUse: Quick simplification using Pythagorean identity.

commonMistakes.why: Must recognize Pythagorean identity form.
Division, not subtraction.

problems.correctAnswer: \text{Verified using difference of squares and Pythagorean identity}

steps.latex: (\sec x - \tan x)(\sec x + \tan x) = \sec^2 x - \tan^2 x

solutions.whenToUse: Recognize algebraic patterns (difference of squares).

steps.latex: \left(\frac{1}{\cos x} - \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\right)\left(\frac{1}{\cos x} + \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\right)

solutions.whenToUse: When you want to verify from first principles.

commonMistakes.why: Middle terms cancel in difference of squares.

commonMistakes.mistake: \text{Not knowing Pythagorean identity with sec and tan}
commonMistakes.why: Must memorize all forms of Pythagorean identities.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Verify: (sec x - tan x)(sec x + tan x) = 1

steps.explanation: Substitute tan x = sin x / cos x.

solutions.whenToUse: Convert to sin/cos for easier manipulation.

commonMistakes.mistake: \sin x \tan x = \sin^2 x \text{ (forgetting tan is sin/cos)}
commonMistakes.correct: \sin x \tan x = \sin x \cdot \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} = \frac{\sin^2 x}{\cos x}
commonMistakes.why: Must use quotient identity for tangent.

commonMistakes.mistake: \frac{\sin^2 x}{\cos x} + \cos x = \frac{\sin^2 x + \cos x}{\cos x}
commonMistakes.why: cos x = (cos²x)/cos x when finding common denominator.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Simplify: sin x tan x + cos x

problems.prompt: \text{Write equation for sinusoidal function with amplitude 3, period } \pi, \text{ phase shift } \frac{\pi}{4} \text{ right, vertical shift 2 up.}

steps.explanation: General sinusoidal form. A = amplitude, D = vertical shift.
Solve for B from period formula.

solutions.whenToUse: Standard method for writing sinusoidal equations.

commonMistakes.why: B is related inversely to period.
Phase shift C is inside with x: factor out B first.
In form A sin(B(x - C)), positive C shifts right.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Write equation: amp=3, period=π, phase=π/4 right, vert shift=2 up

problems.prompt: \text{A Ferris wheel has diameter 50m, center 30m above ground, rotates once per 2 min. Write height } h(t) \text{ at time } t \text{ (starting at bottom).}

steps.explanation: Half the diameter is the amplitude.
Negative amplitude with cosine starts at minimum.

solutions.whenToUse: For real-world periodic motion problems.

commonMistakes.why: Amplitude is half the total variation (radius, not diameter).

commonMistakes.correct: h(t) = -25\cos(\pi t) + 30 \text{ (negative for starting at bottom)}
commonMistakes.why: Regular cosine starts at maximum; need negative to start at minimum.
Midline is the average of max and min heights.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Ferris wheel: 50m diameter, center 30m high, period 2 min, starts at bottom

problems.prompt: \text{Find amplitude, period, and midline of } f(x) = 4\sin(3x - \pi) - 2.

steps.explanation: Amplitude is absolute value of A.

solutions.whenToUse: Direct reading from sinusoidal equation.

commonMistakes.why: Must use formula, not just B value.
Amplitude is a distance, always positive.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Find amplitude, period, midline: f(x) = 4 sin(3x - π) - 2

problems.prompt: \text{Temperature varies from 10°C at 4am to 26°C at 4pm. Model } T(t) \text{ where } t \text{ is hours after midnight.}

solutions.strategy: Find amplitude, midline, period, phase shift
solutions.whenToUse: Temperature and other daily periodic phenomena.

commonMistakes.why: Amplitude is half the total variation.
B = 2π/period, not period itself.

commonMistakes.correct: \text{Phase shift or use negative cosine to match minimum at } t = 4
commonMistakes.why: Must match the specific timing given.

dyslexiaMode.simplifiedPrompt: Model temp: 10°C at 4am, 26°C at 4pm, t = hours after midnight
